case_name: State of Madras v. Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan and State of Madras v. C.R. Srinivasan

facts.text: Appeals numbered Cases Nos. 270 and 271 of 1951 filed under Article 132 of the Constitution from Madras High Court judgment dated 27th July 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION.--Cases Nos. 270 an d 27 1 of 1951, Appeals under Art. 132  1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated 27th July, 1950, of the Madras High Court in certain applic

facts.text: Petitioners filed applications under Article 226 for writ of mandamus restraining State of Madras from enforcing Communal G.O. for admissions to Medical and Engineering Colleges.

anchor.surface_text: the Madras High Court in certain applications under Art. 226 of the Constitution for protection of the fundamental rights of the petitioners under Art. 15  1  and Art. 29  2  of the Constitution and praying for the issue of a writ of mandamus or other suitable prerogative writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers and subordinates thereof from en- forcing, observing, maintaining or following the order of the Government known as the Communal G.O. which laid down rules to be observed by the selection companymittee in the matter of admission of students to the Medical and Engineer- ing Colleges of the State.

facts.text: State of Madras maintains four Medical Colleges with 330 seats available.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madras maintains four Medical Colleges and only 330 seats are available for students in those four Colleges.

facts.text: Out of 330 seats in Medical Colleges, 17 seats reserved for students from outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these 330 seats, 17 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State and 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are apportioned between four distinct groups of districts in the State.

facts.text: Out of 330 seats in Medical Colleges, 12 seats reserved for discretionary allotment by the State.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these 330 seats, 17 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State and 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are apportioned between four distinct groups of districts in the State.

facts.text: Balance seats in Medical Colleges apportioned between four distinct groups of districts.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these 330 seats, 17 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State and 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are apportioned between four distinct groups of districts in the State.

facts.text: State of Madras maintains four Engineering Colleges with 395 seats available.

anchor.surface_text: Likewise, the State of Madras maintains four Engineer- ing Colleges and the total number of seats available for students in those Colleges are only 395.

facts.text: Out of 395 seats in Engineering Colleges, 21 seats reserved for students from outside the State.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these, 21 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State, 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are appor- tioned between the same four distinct groups of districts.

facts.text: Out of 395 seats in Engineering Colleges, 12 seats reserved for discretionary allotment by the State.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these, 21 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State, 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are appor- tioned between the same four distinct groups of districts.

facts.text: Balance seats in Engineering Colleges apportioned between four distinct groups of districts.

anchor.surface_text: Out of these, 21 seats are reserved for students companying from outside the State, 12 seats are reserved for discretionary allotment by the State and the balance of the seats available are appor- tioned between the same four distinct groups of districts.

facts.text: For many years before commencement of Constitution, seats filled according to Communal G.O. proportions: for every 14 seats, Non-Brahmin Hindus 6, Backward Hindus 2, Brahmins 2, Harijans 2, Anglo-Indians and Indian Christians 1, Muslims 1.

anchor.surface_text: For many years before the companymencement of the Constitu- tion, the seats in both the Medical Colleges and the Engi- neering Colleges so apportioned between the four distinct groups of districts used to be filled up according to cer- tain proportions set forth in what used to be called the Communal G. O. Thus, for every 14 seats to be filled by the selection companymittee, candidates used to be selected strictly on the following basis-- Non-Brahmin  Hindus  6 Backward Hindus 2 Brahmins 2 Harijans 2 Anglo-Indians and Indian Christians 1 Muslims 1

facts.text: Constitution commenced on January 26, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: adhered to even after the companymencement of the Constitution on Janu- ary 26, 1950.

facts.text: Proportion fixed in old Communal G.O. adhered to after commencement of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the proportion fixed in the old Communal G.O. has been adhered to even after the companymencement of the Constitution on Janu- ary 26, 1950.

facts.text: G.O. No. 2208 dated June 16, 1950 laid down rules for selection into Medical Colleges reproducing communal proportions.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, G.O. No. 2208, dated June 16, 1950, laying down rules for the selection of candidates for admis- sion into the Medical Colleges substantially reproduces the companymunal proportion fixed in the old Communal G.O.

facts.text: Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan made application to Madras High Court on June 7, 1950 under Article 226.

anchor.surface_text: On June 7, 1950, Srimathi Champakam Doratrajan made an application to the High Court of Judicature at Madras under article 226 of the Constitution for protection of her funda- mental rights under article 15  1  and article 29  2  of the Constitution

facts.text: Champakam Dorairajan belonged to Brahmin community.

anchor.surface_text: She states that on inquiry she came to know that she would number be admitted to the College as she belonged to the Brahmin companymunity.

facts.text: Champakam Dorairajan did not actually apply for admission to Medical College.

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavit filed in support of her petition, it does number appear that the petitioner had actually applied for admission in the Medical College.

facts.text: State agreed to reserve a seat for Champakam Dorairajan if her High Court application succeeds.

anchor.surface_text: No objection, however, was taken to the maintainability of her petition on the ground of absence of any actual application for admission made by her. On the companytrary, we have been told that the State had agreed to reserve a seat for her, should her application before the High Court succeed.

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed Champakam Dorairajan's application by judgment on July 27, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court by its judgment deliv- ered on July 27, 1950, allowed this application of Srimathi Champakam Dorairajan.

facts.text: State of Madras filed appeal in Case No. 270 of 1951 against High Court judgment in Champakam Dorairajan case.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madras has number companye up before us on appeal which has been numbered Case No. 270 of 1951.

facts.text: C.R. Srinivasan applied for admission to Government Engineering College at Guindy.

anchor.surface_text: Sri Srinivasan who had actually applied for admission into the Government Engineering College at Guindy, filed a petition

facts.text: C.R. Srinivasan passed Intermediate Examination in March 1950 in first class.

anchor.surface_text: In the affidavit filed in support of his petition, the petitioner has stated that he had passed the Intermediate Examination held in March, 1950, in Group 1, passing the said examination in the first class and obtain- ing marks set out in paragraph 1 of his affidavit.

facts.text: C.R. Srinivasan secured 369 marks out of 450 in optionals for Engineering admission.

anchor.surface_text: It will appear that in the optionals which are taken into companysidera- tion in determining the academic test for admission in the Engineering College the petitioner Srinivasan secured 369 marks out of a maximum of 450 marks.

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed C.R. Srinivasan's application by judgment on July 27, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has by the same judgment allowed this application also and the State has filed an appeal which has been numbered 271 of 1951.

facts.text: State filed appeal in Case No. 271 of 1951 against High Court judgment in C.R. Srinivasan case.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has by the same judgment allowed this application also and the State has filed an appeal which has been numbered 271 of 1951.

facts.text: Counsel for State conceded that petitioners would have been admitted if selections made on merits alone.

anchor.surface_text: The learned companynsel appearing for the State of Madras companyceded that these two applicants would have been admitted to the educational institutions they intended to join and they would number have been denied admission if selections had been made on merits alone.

facts.text: Srinivasan secured more marks than many Non-Brahmin candidates selected.

anchor.surface_text: Take the case of the petitioner Srinivasan. It is number disputed that he secured a much larger number of marks than the marks secured by many of the Non-Brahmin candidates and yet the Non-Brahmin candidates who secured less number of marks will be admitted into six out of every 14 seats

filed a petition praying for a writ of mandamus or any other writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers thereof from enforcing, observing, maintaining or following the Communal G.O. in and by which admission into the Engineering College was sought to be regulated in such manner as to infringe and involve the violation of the fundamental right of the petitioner under article 15  1  and article 29  2  of the Constitution.

filed a petition praying for a writ of mandamus or any other writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers thereof from enforcing, observing, maintaining or following the Communal G.O. in and by which admission into the Engineering College was sought to be regulated in such manner as to infringe and involve the violation of the fundamental right of the petitioner under article 15  1  and article 29  2  of the Constitution.

The learned counsel appearing for the State of Madras conceded that these two applicants would have been admitted to the educational institutions they intended to join and they would not have been denied admission if selections had been made on merits alone. Article 29 which occurs in Part III of the Constitution under the head Cultural and Educational Rights runs as follows Any section of the citizens residing in the territo- ry of India or any part thereof having a distinct language, script or culture of its own shall have the right to con- serve the same.

concepts.interpretation: Clause (2) guarantees the fundamental right of an individual citizen to get admission into any educational institution maintained by the State or receiving aid out of State funds and this right is not to be denied on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them. It is a right of the individual citizen and not as a member of any community or class.

anchor.surface_text: He urges that article 46 charges the State with promoting with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and, in particular, of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, and with protecting them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.

concepts.interpretation: Directive principle which cannot override enforceable fundamental rights in Part III as per Article 37.

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out that although this article finds a place in Part IV of the Constitution which lays down certain directive principles of State policy and though the provisions contained in that Part are not enforceable by any Court, the principles therein laid down are nevertheless fundamental for the governance of the country and article 37 makes it obligatory on the part of the State to apply those princi- ples in making laws.

concepts.interpretation: Directive principles expressly made unenforceable by a Court.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: each of his fundamental right. The learned Advocate-General appearing for the State companytends that the provisions of this article have to be read a

anchor.surface_text: The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

concepts.interpretation: Fundamental rights enforceable by appropriate writs.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: is pointed out that although this article finds a place in Part IV of the Constitution which lays down certain directive principles of State policy an

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, it will be noticed that article 16 which guarantees the fundamental right of equality of oppor- tunity in matters of public employment and provides that no citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the State also includes a specif- ic clause in the following terms- Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making, any provision for the reservation of appoint- ments of posts in favour of any backward class of citizens which, in the opinion of the State, is not adequately represented in the services under the State.

concepts.interpretation: Contains clause (4) permitting reservation for backward classes in public employment, omission of similar provision in Article 29 significant.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: or order, except to the extent provided in the appropriate article in Part III. The direc- tive principles of State policy have to companyform to and

anchor.surface_text: The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32. The chapter of Fundamental Rights is sacrosanct and not liable to be abridged by any Legislative or Executive Act or order, except to the extent provided in the appropriate article in Part III. The direc- tive principles of State policy have to conform to and run as subsidiary to the Chapter of Fundamental Rights. In our opinion, that is the correct way in which the provisions found in Parts III and IV have to be understood.

concepts.interpretation: Directive principles must conform to and run subsidiary to fundamental rights; Parts III and IV to be understood with fundamental rights taking precedence.

issues.text: Whether the Communal G.O. violates Articles 15(1) and 29(2) of the Constitution by regulating admissions to Medical and Engineering Colleges on the basis of community reservations thereby denying admission on grounds only of religion, race or caste

anchor.surface_text: the Madras High Court in certain applications under Art. 226 of the Constitution for protection of the fundamental rights of the petitioners under Art. 15  1  and Art. 29  2  of the Constitution and praying for the issue of a writ of mandamus or other suitable prerogative writ restraining the State of Madras and all officers and subordinates thereof from en- forcing, observing, maintaining or following the order of the Government known as the Communal G.O. which laid down rules to be observed by the selection companymittee in the matter of admission of students to the Medical and Engineer-

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Article 46 override or qualify the fundamental rights under Article 29(2) so as to permit the State to maintain the Communal G.O. for reservations in educational admissions

anchor.surface_text: He urges that article 46 charges the State with promoting with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and, in particular, of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, and with protecting them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.

issues.text: Whether the directive principles of State policy in Part IV of the Constitution can override the enforceable fundamental rights in Part III

anchor.surface_text: It is pointed out that although this article finds a place in Part IV of the Constitution which lays down certain directive principles of State policy and though the provisions contained in that Part are not enforceable by any Court, the principles therein laid down are nevertheless fundamental for the governance of the country and article 37 makes it obligatory on the part of the State to apply those princi- ples in making laws.

issues.text: Whether the omission of a provision similar to Article 16(4) in Article 29 indicates that no communal reservations are permitted in admissions to State educational institutions

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, it will be noticed that article 16 which guarantees the fundamental right of equality of oppor- tunity in matters of public employment and provides that no citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the State also includes a specif- ic clause in the following terms- Nothing in this article shall prevent the State from making, any provision for the reservation of appoint- ments of posts in favour of any backward class of citizens which, in the opinion of the State, is not adequately represented in the services under the State.

issues.text: Whether the denial of admission to meritorious candidates like the petitioners under the Communal G.O. is solely on the ground of their caste (Brahmin) violating Article 29(2)

anchor.surface_text: Take the case of the petitioner Srinivasan. It is not disputed that he secured a much larger number of marks than the marks secured by many of the Non-Brahmin candidates and yet the Non-Brahmin candidates who secured less number of marks will be admitted into six out of every 14 seats

issues.text: Whether a person who has not actually applied for admission to an educational institution can maintain a petition under Article 226 complaining of infringement of fundamental rights under Article 29(2)

anchor.surface_text: From the affidavit filed in support of her petition, it does number appear that the petitioner had actually applied for admission in the Medical College. She states that on inquiry she came to know that she would number be admitted to the College as she belonged to the Brahmin companymunity. No objection, however, was taken to the maintainability of her petition on the ground of absence of any actual application for admission made by her.

arguments.claim: Petitioners not denied admission solely because Brahmins but because Brahmin seats filled by more meritorious Brahmins and limited allotment

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that the petitioners are not denied admis- sion only because they are Brahmins but for a variety of reasons, e.g.,  a  they are Brahmins,  b  Brah- mins have an allotment of only two seats out of 14 and  c  the two seats have already been filled up by more meritori- ous Brahmin candidates.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Take the case of the petitioner Srinivasan. It is number disputed that he secured a much larger number of marks than the marks secured by many of the

arguments.court_reasoning: Argument has no force for seats reserved for other communities where denial solely on ground of not belonging to those communities

arguments.claim: Classification in Communal G.O. on basis of religion, race, caste invalid under Article 29(2)

anchor.surface_text: The classification in the Communal G.O. proceeds on the basis of religion, race and caste. In our view, the classi- fication made in the Communal G.O.

holdings.text: The Communal G.O. violates Article 29(2) of the Constitution as it denies admission to qualified candidates solely on grounds of religion, race, caste.

anchor.surface_text: Take the case of the petitioner Srinivasan. It is not disputed that he secured a much larger number of marks than the marks secured by many of the Non-Brahmin candidates and yet the Non-Brahmin candidates who secured less number of marks will be admitted into six out of every 14 seats

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Article 29(2) to facts where meritorious Brahmin candidates denied admission solely due to caste while less meritorious from reserved communities admitted; classification based on religion, race, caste.

holdings.text: Article 46 does not override or qualify Article 29(2); directive principles cannot justify infringement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: He urges that article 46 charges the State with promoting with special care the educational and economic interests of the weaker sections of the people, and, in particular, of the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, and with protecting them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 46 in Part IV unenforceable per Article 37; cannot override enforceable rights in Part III.

holdings.text: Directive principles of State policy in Part IV cannot override fundamental rights in Part III; they must conform subsidiary to fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III which, notwithstanding other provisions, are expressly made enforceable by appropriate Writs, Orders or directions under article 32.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Part III sacrosanct and enforceable via Article 32; Part IV non-enforceable and subsidiary; harmonious construction requires precedence of fundamental rights.

holdings.text: Omission of provision similar to Article 16(4) in Article 29 indicates no power for State to reserve seats for backward classes in educational admissions.

anchor.surface_text: In the next place, it will be noticed that article 16 which guarantees the fundamental right of equality of oppor- tunity in matters of public employment and provides that no citizen shall, on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them, be ineligible for, or discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the State also includes a specif-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 16(4) expressly permits reservations in employment; deliberate omission in Article 29 significant, implying no such exception for education.

holdings.text: Article 29(2) guarantees individual right to admission into State educational institutions, not to be denied on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language or any of them.

anchor.surface_text: The learned counsel appearing for the State of Madras conceded that these two applicants would have been admitted to the educational institutions they intended to join and they would not have been denied admission if selections had been made on merits alone. Article 29 which occurs in Part III of the Constitution under the head Cultural and Educational Rights runs as follows

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of clause (2): protects individual citizen, not community; denial only on prohibited grounds breaches right.

holdings.text: Classification in Communal G.O. on basis of religion, race and caste is invalid under Article 29(2).

anchor.surface_text: The classification in the Communal G.O. proceeds on the basis of religion, race and caste. In our view, the classi- fication made in the Communal G.O.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of Article 29(2) prohibition to the G.O.'s communal proportions.

holdings.text: Petitioners not denied admission for variety of reasons but solely on ground of caste.

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that the petitioners are not denied admis- sion only because they are Brahmins but for a variety of reasons, e.g.,  a  they are Brahmins,  b  Brah- mins have an allotment of only two seats out of 14 and  c  the two seats have already been filled up by more meritori-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's multi-factor argument; for non-Brahmin seats, denial solely because not member of reserved community (caste).

holdings.text: Court does not decide whether person without actual application for admission can maintain Article 226 petition under Article 29(2).

anchor.surface_text: No objection, however, was taken to the maintainability of her petition on the ground of absence of any actual application for admission made by her. On the contrary, we have been told that the State had agreed to reserve a seat for her, should her application before the High Court succeed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not pursued as State conceded and reserved seat; guarded observation only.

anchor.surface_text: We reject the above numbered companytentions companypletely. The directive principles of the State policy, which by article 37 are expressly made unen- forceable by a Court, cannot override the provisions found in Part III

outcome.relief_summary: State's contentions rejected; Communal G.O. violates Article 29(2) as it denies admission on grounds of caste, religion, race
